title: Pope Baptizes Babies in Special Church Ceremony
summary: Pope Leo XIV baptized 20 babies in the Sistine Chapel at the Vatican. This is a special tradition that happens every year to mark the end of the Christmas season. The babies are children of people who work at the Vatican. During the ceremony, the Pope talked about how faith is important for life, just like food and clothing are needed to live. He gave each family a candle to represent light and hope. The event celebrates Jesus' baptism and has been done since 1981. The babies were calm and did not cry much during the baptism.

background_read: The Vatican is a small independent city-state in Rome, Italy, where the Pope, the leader of the Catholic Church, lives. Baptism is an important ceremony in Christianity where a person, often a baby, is welcomed into the church with water. The Sistine Chapel is a famous chapel in the Vatican known for its ceiling painted by Michelangelo. Traditions like this baptism ceremony help celebrate religious events and bring people together in faith.
